concurrency.title: Worker Concurrency
concurrency.description: Concurrency controls how many jobs each worker processes simultaneously. Higher values can improve throughput but use more system resources (CPU and memory).
concurrency.configureDescription: To adjust concurrency, set environment variables and restart workers. See documentation for details.

pause.confirmDescription: This will prevent new jobs from being processed. Active jobs will continue to completion.

resume.confirmDescription: This will allow the queue to process waiting jobs.

clean.confirmDescription: This will remove completed and failed jobs from the queue. This action cannot be undone.

drain.confirmDescription: This will remove all waiting jobs from the queue. Active jobs will continue to completion. This action cannot be undone.

obliterate.confirmDescription: This will completely wipe the queue, removing all jobs regardless of state. This action cannot be undone and should only be used in emergency situations.

actions.irreversible: This action cannot be undone. Please confirm you want to proceed.

forceRemove.title: Force Remove Job
forceRemove.question: Do you want to force remove this job?
forceRemove.warning: This will attempt to remove it multiple times with delays. Note: If the job is truly locked by a running worker, it may still fail.

project.name:
## Project Name
The unique identifier for your project.

- Must be unique across all projects
- Used in navigation and reports
- Should be clear and descriptive
- Helps team members identify the project scope
project.description:
## Project Description
Additional details about the project's purpose and scope.

- Optional but recommended
- Helps team members understand project goals
- Can include key objectives or requirements
- Limited to 256 characters
project.icon:
## Project Icon
A visual identifier for your project.

- Helps quickly identify the project in lists and dashboards
- Choose from a variety of predefined icons
- Can be changed at any time
- Appears in project navigation and reports
project.completed:
## Project Status
Indicates whether the project is active or completed.

- Active projects are available for testing and updates
- Completed projects are read-only
- Affects project visibility in dashboards
- Can be reversed if needed
project.completedAt:
## Completion Date
The date when the project was marked as completed.

- Automatically set when marking a project as completed
- Used for reporting and tracking
- Helps maintain project history
- Can be modified if needed
project.defaultAccess:
## Default Project Access
Define the default access permissions for users and groups in this project. This can be overridden on a per-user or per-group basis.
project.issueTracker:
## Issue Tracker Configuration
Select the issue tracker configuration to be used for managing issues related to this project.

integrations.externalProjectHelp:
## External Project
Select the project or repository in the external system to link with this TestPlanIt project.

- Issues created from TestPlanIt will be created in this project
- Enables issue tracking integration between systems
- Must have appropriate permissions in the external system
integrations.defaultIssueTypeHelp:
## Default Issue Type
The issue type that will be pre-selected when creating new issues from TestPlanIt.

- Saves time by defaulting to your most common issue type
- Can be overridden when creating individual issues
- Must be a valid issue type for the selected external project
- Update this if your workflow changes
integrations.automaticSyncHelp:
## Automatic Sync
Enables automatic synchronization of issue status between TestPlanIt and the external system.

- Issues linked to test cases will update their status automatically
- Helps keep issue tracking consistent across systems
- May increase API usage with the external service
- Can be disabled if manual control is preferred

user.name:
## User Name
The full name of the user.

- Used for identification across the system
- Displayed in assignments and reports
- Must be unique for each user
user.email:
## Email Address
The user's email address for account access.

- Used for system login
- Must be unique for each user
- Used for system notifications
user.password:
## Password
The user's account password.

- Must be at least 4 characters long
- Used for secure account access
- Should be kept confidential
user.token:
## Verification Token
Enter the token you received in your email to verify your account. If you don't have a token, you can request a new one.
user.confirmPassword:
## Confirm Password
Re-enter the password to ensure it was typed correctly.

- Must match the password exactly
- Helps prevent typing errors
- Required for account creation
user.access:
## System Access Level
Determines the user's system-wide permissions.

- **Admin:** Full system access and configuration
- **Project Admin:** Can manage assigned projects
- **User:** Standard access to assigned projects
- **None:** Can only view their dashboard
user.role:
## System Role
This role determines the user's default project permissions.

- Defines default access levels for projects
- Can be customized in Role Administration
- Affects available features and capabilities
user.active:
## Active Status
Controls whether a user can access the system.

- Active users can sign in and access their assigned resources
- Inactive users cannot sign in but their data is preserved
  - Use this to temporarily disable access without deleting the account
user.api:
## API Access
Enables programmatic access to the system via API endpoints.

- Allows integration with external tools and automation
- Requires API key authentication
- Subject to rate limiting and access controls
user.projects:
## Project Assignment
Select which projects this user can access.

- Controls which projects appear in the user's dashboard
- Required for project participation
- Can be modified later by administrators
- Use "Select All" to quickly assign all available projects
user.groups:
## Group Assignment
Select which groups this user belongs to.

- Groups help organize users and permissions
- Users inherit permissions from their groups
- Simplifies access management
- Can be modified later by administrators
user.itemsPerPage:
## Items Per Page
Controls the default number of items shown in tables and lists.

- Affects all paginated views in the application
- Can be changed at any time
- Helps manage large data sets efficiently
- Available options: 10, 25, 50, or 100 items
user.dateFormat:
## Date Format
Sets your preferred date display format.

- Applied consistently across the application
- Helps ensure date interpretation accuracy
- Changes take effect immediately
- Examples shown in the dropdown reflect the actual format
user.timeFormat:
## Time Format
Sets your preferred time display format.

- Choose between 12-hour and 24-hour formats
- Applied consistently across the application
- Changes take effect immediately
- Examples shown in the dropdown reflect the actual format
user.timezone:
## Timezone
Sets your preferred timezone for date and time display.

- Applied consistently across the application
user.theme:
## Theme
Choose your preferred visual theme for the application.

- **System:** Automatically matches your operating system theme
- **Light:** Clean, bright interface for daytime use
- **Dark:** Eye-friendly dark mode for low-light environments
- **Green, Orange, Purple:** A fun pop of color!
user.locale:
## Language
Select your preferred language for the application interface.

- Changes all text, labels, and messages to your chosen language
- Date and time formats adjust to match regional conventions
- Takes effect immediately without requiring a page refresh
- Available languages depend on installed translations
user.notificationMode:
## Notification Preferences
Controls how you receive notifications for work assignments and updates.

- **Use Global Settings:** Follow the system default set by administrators
- **No Notifications:** Disable all notifications
- **In-App Only:** Receive notifications only within the application
- **In-App + Email (Immediate):** Get both in-app notifications and immediate email alerts
- **In-App + Email (Daily Digest):** Get in-app notifications and a daily email summary

You can change this preference at any time to suit your workflow.

milestone.name:
## Milestone Name
A clear, descriptive name that identifies this milestone in your project.

- Should be unique and meaningful
- Helps team members quickly understand the milestone's purpose
- Used in reports and project tracking
milestone.type:
## Milestone Type
Categorizes the milestone and determines its appearance and behavior.

- Different types may have different workflows
- Helps organize and filter milestones
- May affect reporting and tracking
milestone.started:
## Started Status
Indicates that work on this milestone has begun.

- Marks the milestone as in progress
- Updates the actual start date automatically when toggled
- Affects project timeline and progress tracking
milestone.completed:
## Completed Status
Indicates that work on this milestone is finished.

- Marks the milestone as done
- Updates the actual completion date automatically
- Used for progress tracking and reporting
- Affects dependent milestones and project timelines
milestone.startDate:
## Planned Start Date
The date when work on this milestone is expected to begin.

- Helps with project planning and scheduling
- Used for timeline projections
- Supports resource allocation planning
milestone.dueDate:
## Due Date
The target date for completing this milestone.

- Sets deadline expectations
- Used for project timeline planning
- Helps track milestone progress against schedule
milestone.parent:
## Parent Milestone
Links this milestone to a parent milestone, creating a hierarchy.

- Organizes milestones into logical groups
- Shows dependencies and relationships
- Helps track progress of larger initiatives
milestone.description:
## Description
Detailed information about the milestone's purpose, requirements, and scope.

- Provides context for team members
- Documents key requirements and objectives
- Supports collaboration and alignment
milestone.documentation:
## Documentation
Additional details, references, and supporting materials.

- Technical specifications
- Design documents
- External references
- Meeting notes and decisions
milestone.automaticCompletion:
## Auto-Complete on Due Date
Automatically marks this milestone as completed when its due date is reached.

- Milestone will be completed at the scheduled time on the due date
- Useful for time-boxed milestones that should close regardless of completion status
- Can be overridden by manually completing the milestone before the due date
- Requires a due date to be set
milestone.notifyDaysBefore:
## Notify Days Before Due Date
Send notifications to assigned team members when the milestone due date is approaching.

- Toggle on to enable notifications, off to disable
- Enter the number of days before the due date to start sending reminders
- Notifications are sent to users assigned to test runs and sessions within this milestone
- Overdue milestones will continue to send reminders until completed

session.name:
## Session Name
A clear, descriptive name that identifies the purpose of your testing session.

- Should be unique and meaningful
- Helps team members understand what is being tested
- Used in reports and tracking
session.template:
## Template
Templates define the structure and content of your testing session.

- Provides a consistent format for test documentation
- Includes predefined sections and fields
- Helps maintain testing standards across your project
session.configuration:
## Configuration
The specific environment or setup required for this testing session.

- Test environment (e.g., Staging, Production)
- Special configurations or settings
- Required test data or conditions
session.milestone:
## Milestone
Associates this session with a project milestone.

- Helps track testing progress towards project goals
- Groups related testing sessions
- Supports milestone-based reporting
session.description:
## Description
A brief overview of what this testing session covers.

- Key areas or features being tested
- Important context or background
- Special considerations or requirements
session.mission:
## Mission
The mission defines the specific objectives and goals for this testing session.

- What are you testing?
- What are the key areas of focus?
- What are the expected outcomes?

A clear mission helps keep testing focused and productive.
session.estimate:
## Time Estimate
Estimated time to complete this testing session.

Examples:
- "30m" for 30 minutes
- "1h 30m" for 1 hour and 30 minutes
- "2 days" for 2 days
- "1 week" for 1 week
session.elapsed:
## Elapsed Time
The actual time spent on this testing session.

Examples:
- "45m" for 45 minutes
- "2h 15m" for 2 hours and 15 minutes
- "3 days" for 3 days

Track time accurately to improve future estimates.
session.state:
## Workflow State
The current status of this testing session in your workflow.

- Helps track session progress
- Supports workflow management
- Used for reporting and tracking
session.assignedTo:
## Assigned To
The team member responsible for conducting this testing session.

- Identifies who is performing the testing
- Helps with resource management
- Supports accountability and tracking
session.tags:
## Tags
Keywords or labels that help categorize and organize testing sessions.

- Makes sessions easier to find
- Groups related testing activities
- Supports filtering and reporting
session.attachments:
## Attachments
Files, screenshots, or other documents related to this testing session.

- Test data files
- Screenshots or recordings
- Supporting documentation
- Reference materials
session.issues:
## Issues
Link relevant issues to this session.

testRun.name:
## Test Run Name
Enter a descriptive name for this test run to easily identify it later.
testRun.description:
## Description
Provide a brief summary or notes about this test run.
testRun.configuration:
## Configurations
Select one or more configurations (e.g., environment, browser, device) under which test runs will be executed. Selecting multiple configurations will create separate test runs for each.
testRun.milestone:
## Milestone
Associate this test run with a specific project milestone to track progress towards larger goals.
testRun.docs:
## Documentation
Include any relevant documentation, links, or detailed notes for this test run.
testRun.state:
## State
Indicate the current status or outcome of this test run according to your project's workflow.
testRun.tags:
## Tags
Apply relevant tags to categorize and filter this test run.
testRun.issues:
## Issues
Link any related issues (bugs, tasks, etc.) to this test run.
testRun.attachments:
## Attachments
Upload any supporting files, screenshots, or logs related to this test run.

duplicate.statusesToInclude:
## Statuses to Include
Select the statuses of test cases you want to include in the duplicated test run.
duplicate.copyAssignments:
## Copy Assignments
If enabled, the assignments of the test cases will be copied to the duplicated test run.

appConfig.key:
## Key
The unique identifier for this configuration.
appConfig.value:
## Value
The value of this configuration.

milestoneType.icon:
## Milestone Type Icon
A visual identifier for this milestone type.

- Helps quickly identify the milestone type in lists and dashboards
- Choose from a variety of predefined icons
- Can be changed at any time
- Appears in project navigation and reports
milestoneType.name:
## Milestone Type Name
A clear, descriptive name that identifies this milestone type in your project.

- Helps team members quickly understand the milestone type's purpose
- Used in reports and project tracking
milestoneType.isDefault:
## Default Milestone Type
Indicates whether this milestone type is the default for your project.

- Default milestone type is pre-selected for new milestones
- Can be changed at any time
milestoneType.projects:
## Associated Projects
Select which projects this milestone type will be available for.

- If no projects are selected, the milestone type will be available globally
- Assigning to specific projects restricts its use to only those projects

tag.name:
## Tag Name
A clear, concise, descriptive name or keyword(s) that is used across all projects.

- Helps team members quickly find related test cases, test runs and sessions.

role.name:
## Role Name
A clear, concise, descriptive name or keyword(s) that is used across all projects.

- Helps team members quickly find related test cases, test runs and sessions.
role.isDefault:
## Default Role
Indicates whether this role is the default for your project.

- Default role is pre-selected for new users
- Can be changed at any time

permissions.canAddEdit:
## Add/Edit
Indicates whether this role can add and edit the related application area.
permissions.canDelete:
## Delete
Indicates whether this role can delete the related application area.
permissions.canClose:
## Close
Indicates whether this role can close the related application area.

group.name:
## Group Name
A clear, concise, descriptive name or keyword(s) that is used across all projects.

- Helps team members quickly find related test cases, test runs and sessions.
group.users:
## Users
Indicates the users that are assigned to this group.

template.name:
## Template Name
A unique and descriptive name for this template (e.g., 'Standard Test Case', 'API Test Results').
template.isEnabled:
## Enabled
If checked, this template will be available for selection when creating new test cases or defining test run structures. If a template is set as 'Default', it must also be 'Enabled'.
template.isDefault:
## Default
If checked, this template will be automatically selected for new projects or as the default for all projects if no project-specific default is set. Only one template can be the default across all projects. Enabling this will disable any other template currently set as default.
template.caseFields:
## Case Fields
Select and order the custom fields that will be available when creating or editing test cases using this template.

- Add fields from the dropdown to include them in the template
- Drag and drop to reorder fields
- The order determines how fields appear in forms
- Only enabled case fields are available for selection
- Case fields define the structure and data captured for test cases
template.resultFields:
## Result Fields
Select and order the custom fields that will be available when adding test results using this template.

- Add fields from the dropdown to include them in the template
- Drag and drop to reorder fields
- The order determines how fields appear when entering test results
- Only enabled result fields are available for selection
- Result fields capture additional data specific to test execution outcomes
template.projects:
## Associated Projects
Select which projects this template will be available for. If no projects are selected, the template will be available globally. Assigning a template to specific projects restricts its use to only those projects.

integration.name:
## Integration Name
A descriptive name to identify this integration across the system.

- Must be unique to distinguish from other integrations
- Used in project settings and configuration
- Should clearly indicate the service and purpose
integration.authType:
## Authentication Type
Choose how to authenticate with the external service.

- **API Key:** Simple authentication using email and API token
- **OAuth 2.0:** Secure authentication using OAuth flow
- **Personal Access Token:** Direct token-based authentication
integration.email:
## Email Address
Your account email address for the external service.

- Used for API key authentication
- Must match the account that generated the API token
- Required for Jira and similar services
integration.apiToken:
## API Token
Generate an API token from your account settings in the external service.

- Usually found in Account Settings → Security → API Tokens
- Provides secure access without exposing your password
- Can be revoked and regenerated as needed
integration.jiraUrl:
## Jira URL
The base URL of your Jira instance.

- Format: https://your-site.atlassian.net
- Do not include /browse or other paths
- Must be accessible from this server
integration.clientId:
## OAuth Client ID
The Client ID from your OAuth application configuration.

- Created in the external service's developer console
- Used to identify your application during OAuth flow
- Safe to share in configuration files
integration.clientSecret:
## OAuth Client Secret
The Client Secret from your OAuth application configuration.

- Created alongside the Client ID
- Must be kept confidential and secure
- Used to authenticate your application
integration.personalAccessToken:
## Personal Access Token
A personal access token with appropriate permissions for the external service.

- Generated in your account settings
- Should have permissions for reading and writing issues
- More secure than password authentication
integration.baseUrl:
## URL Pattern
URL pattern for linking to external issues.

- Use '{issueId}' as a placeholder for the issue identifier
- Example: https://example.com/issues/'{issueId}'
- Used for simple URL-based integrations
integration.organizationUrl:
## Organization URL
Your Azure DevOps organization URL.

- Format: https://dev.azure.com/your-org
- Must be accessible from this server
- Used to access Azure DevOps APIs
integration.apiKey:
## API Key
The API key for authentication with the external service.

- Generated in the service's API settings
- Provides programmatic access to the service
- Keep secure and rotate regularly

config.name:
## Configuration Name
A clear, descriptive name that is used across all projects.

- Helps describe the variant cominations that make up the Configuration (e.g. "Chrome, Windows 10",  "Safari/macOS 15.5", "Edge/Windows 11", etc.).

configCategory.name:
## Category Name
A clear, descriptive name that is used across all projects.

- Helps organize variants (e.g. Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge, etc.) into categories (e.g. Browsers).

configVariant.name:
## Variant Name
A clear, descriptive name that is used across all projects.

- Helps describe the variant that is part of a test environment (e.g. Chrome, Safari, Windows 10, Windows 11, macOS 15.5, etc.).

issueConfig.name:
## Issue Configuration Name
A clear, descriptive name that is used across all projects.

- Helps describe the issue configuration (e.g. Jira, GitHub, etc.).
issueConfig.baseUrl:
## Base URL
The base URL for the issue configuration including the issue placeholder (e.g. https://your-jira-instance.atlassian.net/browse/'{issueId}').
issueConfig.systemType:
## System Type
The type of issue tracking system (e.g. LINK Jira, etc.).
issueConfig.isActive:
## Active
Indicates whether this issue configuration is active.
issueConfig.isDefault:
## Default
Indicates whether this issue configuration is the default for your project.

- Default issue configuration is pre-selected for new issues
- Can be changed at any time
issueConfig.projects:
## Projects
Indicates the projects that are assigned to this issue configuration.

issue.name:
## Issue Name
A clear, descriptive name that is used across all projects.

- Helps describe the issue (e.g. "Issue 123", "Bug 456", etc.).
issue.title:
## Issue Title
A human-readable title that describes the issue.

- Provides context about what the issue is about
- Displayed in lists and issue displays
- Should be clear and descriptive
issue.externalKey:
## External Key
The unique key or identifier from the external issue tracking system.

- For JIRA: Issue key like "PROJ-123"
- For GitHub: Issue number like "456"
- For Azure DevOps: Work item ID
- Automatically generates the external URL when saved
issue.externalId:
## External ID
The unique identifier for this issue in the issue tracking system (e.g. "Issue-123", "Bug456", etc.).

- This is used as the issue placeholder in the base URL.
issue.description:
## Description
A brief overview of what this issue covers.

- Key areas or features being tested
- Important context or background
- Special considerations or requirements
issue.project:
## Project
The project this issue is associated with.

- Issues can be linked to test cases across multiple projects
- Setting a primary project helps organize issues
- Can be left empty for cross-project issues
issue.state:
## State
Indicate the current status or outcome of this issue according to your project's workflow.
issue.tags:
## Tags
Apply relevant tags to categorize and filter this issue.
issue.issues:
## Issues
Link any related issues (bugs, tasks, etc.) to this issue.

status.name:
## Status Name
A clear, descriptive name that is used across all projects.

- Helps describe the test result status (e.g. Passed, Failed, Blocked, etc.).
status.color:
## Color
The color of this status.
status.systemName:
## System Name
The name of the status used by the backend system (e.g. database queries, reports, etc.).
status.aliases:
## Aliases
Additional names or synonyms for this status that can be used to link external system statuses to this status.
status.enabled:
## Enabled
Indicates whether this status is enabled.
status.isEnabled:
## Enabled
Indicates whether this status is enabled and available for use.

- When enabled, this status can be selected when recording test results
- Disabled statuses are hidden from selection but preserved in existing results
status.success:
## Success
Indicates whether this status is a success status.
status.isSuccess:
## Success Status
Indicates whether this status represents a successful test outcome.

- Success statuses contribute to pass rate metrics
- Used in reporting and analytics to track test effectiveness
status.completed:
## Completed
Indicates whether this status is a completed status.
status.isCompleted:
## Completed Status
Indicates whether this status represents a completed test execution.

- Completed statuses indicate the test has finished running
- Used to calculate completion rates and progress tracking
status.failure:
## Failure
Indicates whether this status is a failure status.
status.isFailure:
## Failure Status
Indicates whether this status represents a failed test outcome.

- Failure statuses contribute to fail rate metrics
- Used in reporting and analytics to identify issues
status.scope:
## Scope
Indicates the scope of this status (Test Run, Session, Automation).
status.projects:
## Projects
Indicates the projects that can use this status.

workflow.scope:
## Scope
Indicates the scope of this workflow (Test Run, Session, Automation).

- Cannot be changed once the workflow is created.
workflow.iconColor:
## Icon/Color
The icon and color for this workflow.
workflow.name:
## Name
A clear, descriptive name that is used across all projects.

- Helps describe the workflow (e.g. "Draft", "Under Review", "Active", etc.).
workflow.workflowType:
## Type
The type of workflow (Not Started, In Progress, Completed).
workflow.type:
## Workflow Type
The category of workflow state (Not Started, In Progress, Completed).

- Determines how this state affects progress tracking
- Not Started states indicate work hasn't begun
- In Progress states show active work
- Completed states mark finished work
workflow.isDefault:
## Default
Indicates whether this workflow is the default for your project.

- Default workflow is pre-selected for new test runs, sessions and automation.
workflow.isEnabled:
## Enabled
Indicates whether this workflow is enabled.
workflow.isActive:
## Active
Indicates whether this workflow state is active and available for use.

- Active workflows can be selected when updating test runs, sessions, or automation
- Inactive workflows are hidden from selection but preserved in existing items
workflow.projects:
## Projects
Indicates the projects that can use this workflow.

testResult.status:
## Status
Select the overall status of the test execution. The status you choose can affect project metrics and reports.
testResult.elapsedTime:
## Elapsed Time
Enter the total time taken to execute this test case. You can use units like **s** for seconds, **m** for minutes, **h** for hours (e.g., 30s, 5m, 1h 20m).
testResult.resultData:
## Result Details
Provide detailed notes, observations, or any other relevant data about the overall test execution. This can include setup details, steps followed if deviating from the plan, or general comments.
testResult.evidence:
## Evidence/Attachments
Upload any files (e.g., screenshots, logs, data files) that serve as evidence for this test result. These attachments will be linked to this specific result.
testResult.issues:
## Linked Issues
Link any issues from your integrated issue tracker that are related to this test result. This helps in tracking defects or tasks associated with the outcome of this test.
testResult.stepStatus:
## Step Status
Select the status for this specific test step. This allows for granular tracking of progress within a single test case.
testResult.stepElapsedTime:
## Step Elapsed Time
Enter the time taken to execute this specific step. Use units like **s**, **m**, **h** (e.g., 10s, 2m). This is optional.
testResult.stepNotes:
## Step Notes
Add any notes, observations, or data specific to the execution of this test step.
testResult.stepIssues:
## Step Linked Issues
Link issues from your issue tracker that are specifically related to the outcome or observations of this test step.

case.name:

A clear, descriptive name for the test case.
case.state:
## State
Indicate the current Workflow State of this case.
case.template:
## Template
Select the template that this case will use for its case fields and result fields.
case.estimate:

The manually entered estimated time to complete this test case.
case.automated:
## Automated
Indicates whether this test case is automated or not.
case.tags:
## Tags
Apply relevant tags to categorize and filter this case.
case.issues:

Link any related issues (bugs, tasks, etc.) to this case.

folder.name:
## Folder Name
A clear, descriptive name for the folder.
folder.documentation:
## Documentation
Additional details, references, and supporting materials.

A clear, descriptive name for the test cases.
bulkEdit.state:

bulkEdit.estimate:

bulkEdit.automated:

Indicates whether these test cases are automated or not.
bulkEdit.tags:
## Tags
Apply relevant tags to categorize and filter these test cases.
bulkEdit.issues:

Link any related issues (bugs, tasks, etc.) to these test cases.

caseField.displayName:
## Display Name
This is the human-readable name for the field that will be shown to users in forms and views. Make it clear and descriptive.
caseField.systemName:
## System Name
A unique identifier for this field used internally by the system (e.g., in API calls, database queries). It will be auto-generated from the Display Name but can be customized. Must start with a letter. Can only contain letters, numbers, and underscores (no spaces or special characters).
caseField.hint:
## Hint Text (Optional)
Provide a short instruction or example that will appear below the field to guide users. This can clarify expected input or formatting.
caseField.enabled:
## Enabled
Determines if this field is active and available for use in templates and test cases. Disabled fields are hidden and their data is preserved but not used.
caseField.required:
## Required
If checked, users must provide a value for this field when creating or editing a test case using a template that includes this field.
caseField.restricted:
## Restricted
If checked, only users with special permissions (e.g., Super Admins or those with 'Case Restricted Fields' permission) can edit this field's value once a case is created. Other users will see it as read-only. This is useful for fields like 'Reviewed By' or 'Approved Date' that should not be changed by general users after a certain stage.
caseField.fieldType:
## Field Type
Determines the kind of data this field will store and how it will be displayed (e.g., Text, Number, Date, Dropdown). The field type cannot be changed after creation.
caseField.defaultValue:
## Default Value (Optional)
Set a pre-filled value for this field. For 'Checkbox' type, use 'true' or 'false'. For 'Dropdown' or 'Multi-Select', this usually refers to the ID(s) of the default option(s). For other types, it's the literal default text/number. This can be overridden when the field is added to a template.
caseField.isChecked:
## Default State (for Checkbox)
Determines if the checkbox should be checked by default when a new item (e.g., test case) is being created.
caseField.minValue:
## Minimum Value (for Number/Integer)
Sets the smallest allowed numeric value for this field. Both Min and Max Value must be set if one is used.
caseField.maxValue:
## Maximum Value (for Number/Integer)
Sets the largest allowed numeric value for this field. Both Min and Max Value must be set if one is used.
caseField.initialHeight:
## Initial Height (for Text Long)
Specify the initial display height (in pixels) for rich text editor fields. This helps control the form layout for longer text inputs.
caseField.dropdownOptions:
## Options (for Dropdown/Multi-Select)
Define the list of choices available for selection. You can reorder options, set a default, and enable/disable individual options.

resultField.displayName:
## Display Name
This is the human-readable name for the field that will be shown to users when entering test results. Make it clear and descriptive.
resultField.systemName:
## System Name
A unique identifier for this field used internally by the system (e.g., in API calls, database queries). It will be auto-generated from the Display Name but can be customized.
- Must start with a letter.
- Can only contain letters, numbers, and underscores (no spaces or special characters).
resultField.hint:
## Hint Text (Optional)
Provide a short instruction or example that will appear below the field to guide users. This can clarify expected input or formatting when entering result data.
resultField.enabled:
## Enabled
Determines if this field is active and available for use in templates when entering test results. Disabled fields are hidden and their data is preserved but not used.
resultField.required:
## Required
If checked, users must provide a value for this field when adding a test result using a template that includes this field.
resultField.restricted:
## Restricted
If checked, only users with special permissions (e.g., Super Admins or those with 'Test Run Result Restricted Fields' permission) can edit this field's value once a result is submitted. Other users will see it as read-only.
resultField.fieldType:
## Field Type
Determines the kind of data this field will store and how it will be displayed for test results (e.g., Text, Number, Date, Dropdown). The field type cannot be changed after creation.
resultField.defaultValue:
## Default Value (Optional)
Set a pre-filled value for this field when adding a new test result. For 'Checkbox' type, use 'true' or 'false'. For 'Dropdown' or 'Multi-Select', this usually refers to the ID(s) of the default option(s). For other types, it's the literal default text/number.
resultField.isChecked:
## Default State (for Checkbox)
Determines if the checkbox should be checked by default when a new test result is being added.
resultField.minValue:
## Minimum Value (for Number/Integer)
Sets the smallest allowed numeric value for this field when entering result data. Both Min and Max Value must be set if one is used.
resultField.maxValue:
## Maximum Value (for Number/Integer)
Sets the largest allowed numeric value for this field when entering result data. Both Min and Max Value must be set if one is used.
resultField.initialHeight:
## Initial Height (for Text Long)
Specify the initial display height (in pixels) for rich text editor fields used in results. This helps control the form layout for longer text inputs.
resultField.dropdownOptions:
## Options (for Dropdown/Multi-Select)
Define the list of choices available for selection when entering result data. You can reorder options, set a default, and enable/disable individual options.

exportModal.scope:
## Export Scope
Determines which test cases will be included in the export:
- **Selected:** Exports only the test cases you have explicitly selected in the table.
- **All Filtered:** Exports all test cases that match the current filter criteria in the table, even if not all are currently visible on the page.
- **All Project:** Exports every test case in the current project, ignoring any selections or filters.
exportModal.format:
## Export Format
Choose the file format for your export.
- **CSV (Comma Separated Values):** A plain text file suitable for spreadsheets (Excel, Google Sheets) and data analysis tools. PDF export is planned for a future release.
exportModal.columns:
## Columns to Export (CSV Only)
Determines which data columns will be included for each test case:
- **All Columns:** Exports all available data fields for the test cases, including custom fields from their templates.
- **Visible Columns:** Exports only the columns currently visible in the test case table.
exportModal.delimiter:
## CSV Delimiter (CSV Only)
Choose the character used to separate values in the CSV file. The most common is Comma. Use a different delimiter if your data contains commas within text fields (e.g., Semicolon).
exportModal.textLongFormat:
## Long Text Field Format (CSV Only)
Determines how rich text fields (like 'Description' or custom 'Text Long' fields) are exported:
- **JSON:** Exports the content as a JSON string, preserving all formatting (bold, lists, etc.). This is best for re-importing or programmatic processing.
- **Plain Text:** Exports the content as plain text, stripping out formatting. This is more readable in simple text viewers.
exportModal.stepsFormat:
## Steps Format (CSV Only)
Determines how test steps (including expected results) are exported:
- **JSON:** Exports steps as a JSON array of objects, preserving structure and rich text. Suitable for re-import or detailed analysis.
- **Plain Text:** Exports steps in a simplified, readable plain text format, with each step and expected result on a new line.
exportModal.rowMode:
## Row Mode (CSV Only)
Determines how multi-value fields (like Tags or Multi-Select custom fields) and Steps are represented:
- **Single Row per Case:** Each test case is a single row. Multi-value fields and steps will be condensed into their respective cells (often as JSON or concatenated text).
- **Multiple Rows per Case:** A test case can span multiple rows if it has multiple tags, multi-select values, or steps. Each unique value/step for such fields will create a new row, with other case data repeated. This is useful for detailed analysis or pivoting.
exportModal.attachmentFormat:
## Attachment Info Format (CSV Only)
Determines how information about attachments is exported:
- **JSON:** Exports attachment details (like filename, URL, size) as a JSON array. This is comprehensive but less human-readable directly in a CSV.
- **Names Only:** Exports a comma-separated list of attachment filenames. Simpler for quick reference.

reportDimensions.status:

reportDimensions.project:

reportDimensions.testRun:
## Test Run Dimension

reportDimensions.testCase:

reportDimensions.milestone:

reportDimensions.configuration:

reportDimensions.template:

reportDimensions.creator:

reportDimensions.state:

reportBuilder.dimensions:
## Dimensions
Select the dimensions you want to analyze in your report. Dimensions are attributes that categorize your data, such as Date, User, Status, etc. You can drag to reorder them.
reportBuilder.metrics:
## Metrics
Select the metrics you want to measure in your report. Metrics are quantitative measurements derived from your data, such as Test Results Count, Pass Rate, Average Elapsed Time, etc. You can drag to reorder them.
reportBuilder.dateRange:
## Date Range
Filter your report data by a specific time period. You can select from predefined ranges like 'Last 7 days' or 'Previous month', or define a custom date range. This filter applies to the relevant date field for each report type (e.g., execution date for test results, creation date for test cases).

welcome.title: Welcome to TestPlanIt!
welcome.content: Let's take a quick tour of TestPlanIt's key features to help you get started with your testing workflow.

projects.content: Access all your testing projects from here. Each project contains test cases, runs, and team collaboration features.

project.title: Project Card
project.content: Click a project card to view its details. Choose Project Tour from the help menu for a guided tour of project features.

globalFeatures.title: Global Features
globalFeatures.content: Manage Tags for categorization, track Issues across projects, and manage Users with role-based access control.

search.content: Contextual search based on your current page. Find test cases, runs, issues, or any content quickly. Use Cmd+K (or Ctrl+K) for instant access.

help.title: Help & Support
help.content: Access this guided tour anytime or visit our comprehensive documentation for detailed help.

notifications.content: Stay informed about test run completions, issue updates, and team activities. Configure preferences in your account settings.

account.title: Account Menu
account.content: Customize your profile, notification preferences, and account settings. Switch between light and dark themes.

assignments.content: View test cases and runs assigned to you across all projects. This is your personal dashboard to track your testing work.

projectSelector.title: Project Selector
projectSelector.content: Switch between projects quickly using this dropdown. View project details and access project-wide settings.

projectSections.title: Project Sections
projectSections.content: Navigate through Overview for project dashboard, Documentation for project guides, and Milestones for tracking progress.

repository.content: Manage your test cases, organize them into folders, and create new test scenarios for thorough testing coverage.

repositoryPanels.title: Repository Left Panel
repositoryPanels.content: The left panel shows your folder structure and test case tree. Use the view selector to switch between different organizational views.

repositoryRightPanel.title: Repository Right Panel
repositoryRightPanel.content: The right panel displays test case details, execution results, and provides actions to create new test cases or import existing ones.

testRuns.content: Execute planned test runs, track progress, and manage test assignments across your team. View detailed execution results.

testRunsPage.title: Test Runs Dashboard
testRunsPage.content: This is the Test Runs page where you can create new test runs, monitor execution progress, view results, and manage test assignments. Track your team's testing activities from one central location.

sessions.title: Exploratory Sessions
sessions.content: Document exploratory testing sessions, capture findings, and track time spent on ad-hoc testing activities.

sessionsPage.title: Exploratory Sessions Dashboard
sessionsPage.content: This is the Sessions page where you can create and manage exploratory testing sessions. Document findings, track time spent, and maintain a record of all ad-hoc testing activities for better test coverage.

tags.title: Tags Management
tags.content: Organize and categorize your test cases using tags. Create custom tags to improve test case organization and filtering.

issues.title: Issue Tracking
issues.content: Track and manage issues discovered during testing. Link issues to test cases and integrate with external bug tracking systems.

reports.title: Reports & Analytics
reports.content: Generate comprehensive reports and analytics for your project. View test coverage, execution trends, team performance metrics, and create custom reports for stakeholders.

welcome.title: Welcome to Admin Controls
welcome.content: Take a guided tour of TestPlanIt's administrative features. Manage projects, users, configurations, and system settings from this central administration panel.

projects.title: Project Administration
projects.content: Manage all projects in your organization. Create, configure, and archive projects. Set project-wide permissions and access controls.

templatesAndFields.content: Create and manage test case templates and custom fields. Define field types, validation rules, and organize templates for consistent test case structure across projects.

workflows.title: Workflow Management
workflows.content: Define test case workflows and state transitions. Configure how test cases progress through different states like Draft, Review, and Approved.

statuses.title: Test Result Statuses
statuses.content: Configure available test result statuses like Pass, Fail, Blocked, and Skip. Set up custom statuses and define their behavior and appearance.

milestones.content: Define milestone types for project tracking. Configure release types, sprint categories, and other project milestone classifications.

configurations.title: Test Configurations
configurations.content: Manage test configurations and environments. Set up browser combinations, device types, operating systems, and other test execution contexts.

users.title: User Management
users.content: Manage user accounts, permissions, and access levels. Create new users, assign roles, and configure authentication settings.

groups.title: Group Management
groups.content: Organize users into groups for easier permission management. Create department groups, project teams, and role-based access groups.

roles.title: Role Management
roles.content: Define user roles and permissions. Configure what actions different roles can perform across projects and system administration.

tags.title: Global Tags
tags.content: Manage organization-wide tags for categorizing test cases, projects, and other entities. Create tag hierarchies and standardize tagging across projects.

reports.content: Generate reports that span multiple projects. Analyze trends, performance metrics, and organizational testing effectiveness across your entire workspace.

notifications.title: Notification Settings
notifications.content: Configure system-wide notification preferences. Set up email templates, notification rules, and default settings for user notifications.

integrations.title: System Integrations
integrations.content: Manage third-party integrations and API connections. Configure Jira, GitHub, and other external tool integrations for your organization.

llm.title: AI Configuration
llm.content: Configure AI models and settings for automated test case generation and intelligent features. Manage API keys and model preferences.

sso.title: Single Sign-On
sso.content: Configure SSO providers and authentication methods. Set up SAML, OAuth, and other identity provider integrations for seamless user access.

appConfig.content: Manage global application settings and system preferences. Configure default values, feature toggles, and system-wide behaviors.

trash.title: System Trash
trash.content: View and manage deleted items across all projects. Restore accidentally deleted content or permanently purge items from the system.
